issues.title: Remove Werror compiler flag
issues.body:
It's generally considered bad practice to ship software with this flag.
Issue revealed while updating the port on [OpenBSD].

[OpenBSD]: https://marc.info/?l=openbsd-ports&m=151482370923381&w=2

issues.title: Sanbox support for more operating systems
issues.body:
It would be interesting to investigate adding support for sandboxing on
operating systems other than OpenBSD where [pledge] is available.
There's seccomp on Linux and Capsicum on FreeBSD. I wouldn't worry about
the portability at this stage, just the code required to get it working
would be a great start.

[pledge]: http://man.openbsd.org/pledge

issues.title: Create a pick Recipes page, maybe as part of the Wiki
issues.body:
`pick` is really awesome, in less than a month it's become a great friend to me. It makes working with git branches and commits a lot easier, but maybe I wouldn't have thought to use it like that if I hadn't seen the gif in the README.

My point is that pick is a versatile tool whose possibilities aren't necessarily obvious at first. I think having a Wiki-style section for Recipes could bring in creative, cool use cases, and give new users more ideas of how to use pick.

I wrote [a post](http://kylebebak.github.io/post/git-utility-functions-pick) about how I use it with git, I basically wrote some [helper functions](https://github.com/kylebebak/dotfiles/blob/master/dotfiles/.helpers/pick.sh) that wrap pick to make operations with branches and commits very fast.

This is the kind of stuff I think could go into Recipes, snippets of code using pick and gifs showing them in action. If this seems like a good idea I would love to contribute.

issues.title: Stream input
issues.body: pick must read its input entirely before the filtering interface becomes responsive. For an example, in a directory with a large number of entries (say > 150,000), compare `find . -type f | pick`, which will take at least seconds to become responsive, and `find . -type f | less`, which is immediately responsive. [fzf](https://github.com/junegunn/fzf) is one example of a fuzzy finder that handles this well by searching over entries received so far and streaming in new entries as they match.

commit.message: Update release notes
Update version to 2.0.1
Update CHANGELOG
Update release notes
Remove a cast since tparm takes a non-const char pointer

travis: execute script in a subshell enabling errexit and xtrace

Enabling errexit on Travis could interfere with their scripts, therefore
use a subshell. The xtrace option makes debugging easier.

Simplify logic used to determine when choices must be re-displayed

Enabling dofilter implies dochoices by now. Therefore, there's no longer
necessary to fiddle with dochoices for each key binding that doesn't
result in filtering of the choices.

Ensure correctness while typing a query fast

Typing a query fast enough to trigger the poll check in filter_choices()
could yield a wrong set of choices. Since filter_choices() is
interrupted, all choices have yet not been examined and potential
matches could still be left unexamined. Calling print_choices() in this
state causes the unexamined choices to never be reconsidered as
potential matches since they will have a score = 0. The solution is to
never call print_choices() if filter_choices() was interrupted.

Problem reported and partial solution provided by Jenz Guenther in
GitHub issue #268.

Bump pick-test timeout

Needed when compiling with the `-coverage' option since it writes
coverage data upon exit. Ideally, the timeout should only be increased
when running under these circumstances. However, the tests finish much
earlier if all is well.

travis: enable codecov.io

Necessary to use the check rather distcheck task since coverage files
will be present causing distcheck to fail.
travis: switch on BUILD_TYPE

Add missing tests for right key

Discovered using lcov:

$ env CFLAGS='-g -O0 -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage' CC=gcc ./configure
$ lcov --base-directory . --directory . --zerocounters -q
$ make check
$ lcov --base-directory . --directory . -c -o pick.info
$ mkdir html
$ genhtml -o html pick.info
$ xdg-open html/index.html
Do not use the escape sequence for literal escape

Allow multiple tests per file to actually run

Do not clear the input file after each test run, obvious mistake since
it only allows one tests per file to be executed. My bad, regression
introduced in commit 54b1e43 ("Add toggle sorting key binding").
Update version to 2.0.0
Update CHANGELOG

Only redraw the choices when necessary

Some key bindings only affect the query and unconditionally redrawing
the choices is therefore a wast of time in such scenarios.

Originally proposed by Jenz Guenther in PR #254.
Add toggle sorting key binding

Fix exit code for h option

Surprised to find out that the h option has been broken from the start.

Do not run each test in a separate process

Fixes a severe bug where the exit code was incorrect for failing tests.
Add missing tests
Fix test failure cause bug
Rename tests to match implementation
Cleanup tests

As of OpenBSD 6.2 pick is now available as a package

Unfortunately, 1.9.0 did not make the cut.
Consolidate tests
Allow multiple tests to be specified in a single file
Error out on mandoc style violations
Fix brew runtime error on travis

Rename DEVELOPING.md -> CONTRIBUTING.md

In order to match the conventions defined by GitHub.

issue_comments.body:
Great change, and the extracted `memmove()` is a good idea.

Wishlist: `^k`. Actual emacs users don't use `^u` or `^w` but hammer on `^k` all day.
Thanks for the feedback! I will work on this more tomorrow night or on Friday. @mike-burns What does <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>K</kbd></kbd> do?

<kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>k</kbd></kbd> will delete until the end of line. In actual emacs, to delete a whole line you'd type <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>a</kbd> <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>u</kbd></kbd>.

(In emacs, <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>u</kbd></kbd> will add a number in front of a command, so e.g. <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>u</kbd> <kbd>4</kbd> <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>;</kbd></kbd> will comment out four lines.)
Comments are addressed and <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>K</kbd></kbd> is implemented. Ready for another pass.
My C's a little rusty, but this looks good to me.
Thanks @georgebrock. Merging.
Me and Jack discussed this IRL and agreed on it being ready to be merged in.
+1 Can reproduce locally in iTerm on OS X
This is awesome @Keithbsmiley! Thanks a lot for figuring this out. Merge at your discretion.

This still appears to be an issue with these steps:
1. Open vim
2. Open your pick search
3. Hit CTRL-C to exit pick without choosing a file
4. Quit vim
Assuming we choose to go this way we may want to add this to the man page as well.

Thanks for reporting this, @Keithbsmiley.

`bsd/string.h` is included for the `strlcpy` function for safely copying strings.

Maybe we could check for the existence of `strlcpy` and include a bundled version if it's not available, like @mike-burns does [in Argonaut](https://github.com/bitptr/argonaut/blob/7377e106c2a855a82f7571a276a38a63dde18724/src/compat.c)?

Running in raw mode will make `ncurses` pass through all characters, including those used for quit, interrupt, suspend and flow control.

Maybe we could use `signal(3)` to trap `SIGINT` to avoid passing through all of them and just handling the interrupt signal?
I had one small comment, other than that, this looks good to merge. Thanks for adding this, @Keithbsmiley!
:+1: got this signal method to work locally. I'll clean it up tomorrow.
Thanks, @Keithbsmiley.
That's what I recommend. I especially recommend using the system library when possible; libbsd does its best to stay up-to-date but your OS gets security patches more often.
This is the other piece of glue, BTW: https://github.com/bitptr/argonaut/blob/master/configure.ac#L6
@calleerlandsson updated with signals.

I can reproduce this locally. This bug did not manifest itself before we added the call to `refresh` in dcc7a8bb52be649cc55a37c9e2b7dee3ab63d2f0. 

Reading `curs_initscr(3X)` it seems like the call to `refresh` after the call to `endwin` might bring us back into curses mode:

```
A program should always call endwin before exiting or escaping from curses mode tem‐
porarily.   This routine restores tty modes, moves the cursor to the lower left-hand
corner of the screen and resets the terminal into the proper non-visual mode.  Call
ing refresh or doupdate after a temporary escape causes the program to resume visual
mode.
```
Looks great @Keithbsmiley, I had some style comments and one question.
@calleerlandsson updated!
Since calling refresh when running in Vim seems to be what we want should we be trying to do that conditionally?
@Keithbsmiley I had one question, other than that, this looks great to merge! Thanks!

This looks good!

The build is currently failing on my system because I don't have the `strlcpy`function in my `string.h`. Therefore, the `strlcpy.c` needs to be conditionally included. One example of how this is done is how `compat/queue.h` gets included in `src/choices.c`.

I have left some comments on how I think it could be fixed. I totally understand if you don't have time to work on this @Keithbsmiley and I can finish this tomorrow.

Here is my make output:

```
~/Projects/pick $ make

Yeah, that seem like a good approach. The question is what we should switch on.

I think this has to do with the state of the terminal when `pick` gets executed. By having a quick look at `ncurses(3X)`, I think logging the return values of these functions when `pick` starts and ends might tell us more:

```
is_cleared              curs_opaque(3X)*
is_idcok                curs_opaque(3X)*
is_idlok                curs_opaque(3X)*
is_immedok              curs_opaque(3X)*
is_keypad               curs_opaque(3X)*
is_leaveok              curs_opaque(3X)*
is_linetouched          curs_touch(3X)
is_nodelay              curs_opaque(3X)*
is_notimeout            curs_opaque(3X)*
is_scrollok             curs_opaque(3X)*
is_syncok               curs_opaque(3X)*
is_term_resized         resizeterm(3X)*
is_wintouched           curs_touch(3X)
isendwin                curs_initscr(3X)
```

@Keithbsmiley I have pushed the changes I suggested. It also turned out that we needed `strlcat` from `bsd/string.h` so I grabbed the OpenBSD implementation of that aswell.

@Keithbsmiley @mike-burns can you try to build this locally and see if I screwed something up?

```

commit_comments.body: That's not a thing. Did you mean `-v` ?
These aren't needed for Homebrew-ing. Were I doing it all over again, I wouldn't have a `release` target.
Might be worth noting: I just switched rcm from a Makefile-driven release to a sh-driven release, and it's given me more flexibility: https://github.com/thoughtbot/rcm/blob/master/maint/release.in
I did, thanks for pointing it out
Sounds great~ I atleast understand `sh` better than `make`
@mike-burns Sounds interesting. In what way is it more flexible?

You're right, "flexible" is the wrong word. It's more that m4sh has a harder syntax than normal sh; it's all of sh's syntax combined with all of m4's syntax combined with all of make's syntax. Because of this, I extracted it.
This commit LGTM.
Rest in peace, alignment. This commit seems fine, despite the fact that it now diverges from my coding style.
Good change. This commit LGTM.

style(9) says:

> Prototypes may have an extra space after a tab to enable function names to line up

I interpreted "may" as "optional". Is the space optional but the tab not? Should it be _a_ tab specifically? I do think following the style guide is important.

All the examples in style(9) show tabs + an optional space in function prototypes to get things aligned. The guide itself is unclear about the specifics.

Would it be jarring to have a file with the tabs and a file without the tabs in the same project (but separate files)?
You could drop the braces here.
Ah, you added braces everywhere. OK!
Nice.
I like it.

Ouch; is this for an 80 char limit? I feel like violating that guideline here would make it easier to read.

(Perhaps this is changed in a later commit anyway...)
Does this handle multiplication overflow issues/should you use reallocarray(3) instead?
[We talked IRL; the tabs go back.]
Can this use calloc(3) to avoid multiplication overflow concerns?

style(9) says:

> Use a space after keywords (if, while, for, return, switch). No braces are used for control statements with zero or only a single statement unless that statement is more than a single line, in which case they are permitted.
LGTM.
This is beautiful poetry.

Overall: I'm into it. Though I don't mind `str`, `desc`, and `len` -- those seem clear and common enough to me. But I also don't mind `string`, `description`, and `length`.

So anyway: LGTM.
Great.
Beautiful.
Yes.
I'm not sold on this abstraction. Why is `raw_tty_putc` a separate function?
Lovely.
Great abstraction.

review_comments.body: This code is repeated. Maybe extract a `void reset()` function?
Is there a more expressive name for this variable? e.g. `word_pos`?
Does it make sense to `#define` away these magic numbers, so that they are consistent with `KEY_LEFT` etc.?
Seems like a good idea.
Extracted as `filter_choices` in 2d8d063.
`word_pos` is much better. Changed in 2061c44.
Great point. Done in 62a52a2.

review_comments.body: I'm glad you asked. `KEY_ENTER` is defined in `ncurses.h` and is really <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>Enter</kbd></kbd>. Very confusing.
Style question: is it more normal to pre-decrement? I find the post-decrement operator (i.e. `cursor_pos--`) easier to read, but possibly only because I'm more used to seeing it.

review_comments.body: Good point. Added in ebd3453.

Good question. I don't actually know. I tend to use pre-decrement operator because I find that it makes more sense for the expression to evaluate to the decremented value, not the original. I only use the post-decrement operator when I really mean it. In this case it does not matter since we just throw the value away. I guess it is just a habit. @mike-burns Do you know what's the normal thing to do here?
I think it should be 'parse_desc == 1' or 'parse_desc != 0' inside the parens, just for clarity's sake.
It looks like line is never freed.
Thanks for finding that. Confirmed the leak with valgrind(1) and fixed it in b964aa5.
Since we're using `int`s as booleans in other places I think I prefer to stick to this style for consistency.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@ The
 .Xr ncurses 3X
 interface is operated with the following keys:
 .Bl -tag -width Backspace
-.It Ic "Up\&/Down"
+.It Ic "Up/Ctrl\&-N\&/Down/Ctrl\&-P"
review_comments.body:
Would specifying these in the same order as "Left/Right or Ctrl-B/Ctrl-F" make sense?

I'm thinking something like:

```
.It Ic "Up\&/Down or Ctrl\&-P\&/Ctrl\&-N"
```
Should we error in this scenario or should we `exit`? I feel like interrupting pick is a part of normal execution and therefor I think `exit` might be better.

Could `130` be extracted into `EX_SIGINT`?

```
#define EX_SIG 128
#define EX_SIGINT (EX_SIG + SIGINT)
```

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,13 @@
+Contributing
+============
+
+Pull requests are very welcome. Here's a quick guide on how to contribute:
+
+- Fork and clone the repo.
+- Set up your build environment in accordance to the instructions in
+  `DEVELOPING.md`.
+- Make your changes.
+- Update `man/man1/pick.1` and `README.md` in accordance to your changes.
+- Make sure `pick(1)` builds and runs as expected: `make && src/pick`.
